ENTRY.refkeywords: deep copy cp data id ID ids IDs
ENTRY.SYNOPSIS: Copy a data set by data ID to a new data ID (deep copy)

DESC.PARA: The copy_data() function performs a deep copy operation in which one data set is fully copied to another.

LIST.ITEM: fromid - the id of the source data set
toid - id of the destination data set

DESC.PARA: The copy_data() function copies one data set to another, by data set ID. Here, the data contained in data set 2 is copied to data set "src".
DESC.VERBATIM:
sherpa> print(get_data(2)) name = simple.pi channel = Float64[1024] counts = Float64[1024] staterror = None syserror = None bin_lo = None bin_hi = None grouping = None quality = None exposure = 56494.4943719 backscal = 9.36267570731e-05 areascal = 1.0 grouped = False subtracted = False units = energy response_ids = [1] background_ids = [1]
sherpa> print(gete_data("src")) name = 1843.pi channel = Float64[1024] counts = Float64[1024] staterror = None syserror = None bin_lo = None bin_hi = None grouping = None quality = None exposure = 7854.46647487 backscal = 0.00085461636003 areascal = 1.0 grouped = False subtracted = False units = energy response_ids = [1] background_ids = []
sherpa> copy_data(2, "src")
sherpa> print(gete_data("src")) name = simple.pi channel = Float64[1024] counts = Float64[1024] staterror = None syserror = None bin_lo = None bin_hi = None grouping = None quality = None exposure = 56494.4943719 backscal = 9.36267570731e-05 areascal = 1.0 grouped = False subtracted = False units = energy response_ids = [1] background_ids = [1]

BUGS.PARA: See the bugs pages on the Sherpa website for an up-to-date listing of known bugs.
